titleStmt.title: Smith, Wentworth, fl. 1601-1623 : : The Hector of Germany (1615)

publicationStmt.publisher: Wentworth Smith, fl. 1601-1623 (fl.1601-1615) The Hector of Germany. Or The Palsgraue; Prime Elector. A New Play, an Honourable History. As it hath beene publickly Acted at the Red-Bull, and at the Curtayne, by a Company of Young-men of this Citie. Made by W. Smith: with new Additions. London Printed at London by Thomas Creede, for Iosias Harrison [etc.] 1615

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
The Hector of Germany. Genre: History. Date first published: 1615. Date first performed: Jan 1614-1615 ?

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Palsgraue. Duke of Sauoy. Old Fitzwaters King of Bohemia Marquesse of Brandenburgh Bishop ofCullen Steward Prince Henry/Bastard. Duke of Saxon Bishop of Mentz Young Fitzwaters Floramell Bishop of Trier Lord Clynton Bishop Peter the Hermit/King of Spain Page King Edward a Lord Poytiers Letter Vandome Mendoza
French King French Queen Duke of Artoise Servant Messenger
Herald Englishman Frenchman

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: A Bed thrust out, the Palsgraue lying sicke in it, the King of Bohemia, the Duke of Sauoy, the Marquesse Brandenburgh, entring with him.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
Sick at this instant now to be infirm,
When the English King hath his kind Letter sent:
For me to place this honourable prince,
The Duke of Sauoy in the Empires rule:
That Nation my great Grandfather did love.
And since I came to understand their valour,
I held them the Prime Soldiers of the world:
And think no Martial Tutor fits a prince,
But he that is a true-born Englishman.
Ill comes this Letter, and your Grace at once,
A worser time than this you could not choose.
Though I am chief Elector of the seven,
And a mere Cæsar now the Chair is void:
Sickness hath weakened all my powers so much,
I shall be slighted as a worthless thing.

sp.speaker: Sauoy.
sp.p: Why should the Palsgraue so mistrust his Friends?

sp.speaker: Palgr:
sp.p:
Sauoy, because I know them factious.
And though Bohemia love me as his life,
And Umpire-like, should pacify our jars,
What is his voice when Saxon draws his sword?
Mentz of a Clergyman is stout and proud,
Trier his like, in nature and in vice.
And the bold Bastard, late expulsed from Spain,
Has a blood-thirsty heart, a vengeful spleen.
Misfortune cannot daunt him though he fled
Out of his own Realm, and has lost his Crown.
His impudency yet aims at Cæsars Throne,
I would freely part with mine inheritance,
If it could purchase health to tame his pride,
But in you only I repose my trust.
Reserve your voices for this Noble Duke,
Who were I well should be an Emperor:
Sickness will be obeyed, I must decline,
For my speech fails me to urge more discourse,
Pray for me all, if that they chance to win,
And I recover I will help all by War.

body.stage: The Bedde drawne in. Exit Palsgraue.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.p:
The strength of Germany is sick in him,
And should he die now in his prime of life,
Like Troy we loose the Hector of our Age:
For he alone, when he was strong and well,
Curbed all their pride, and kept the worst in awe.

sp.speaker: Marqu:
sp.p:
We must expect war: and prepare ourselves
With expedition to resist their force:
For a more dangerous Foe for Treachery,
Than is the Bastard, lives not in these parts.

sp.speaker: Sauoy.
sp.p:
I am sorry, that presuming on the health
Of the most valiant Palsgraue now fallen sick,
I came so ill provided for the Wars.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.p: We are strong enough to meet them in the field.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p:
Prepare for War, the Bastard is in arms,
With him the fiery Saxon, Mentz, and Trier:
And they will besiege this Castle, to constrain
The Palsgraue, to elect him Emperor.

sp.speaker: Marq:
sp.p: Shame to us all, if we give aim to that.

sp.speaker: Sauoy.
sp.p:
Begirt this Castle, and disturb the health
Of our dear friends, it is insufferable.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.p:
Let us convey him lower down the river,
Unto a stronger Castle of his own:
And with such Forces as we have prepared,
Give battle to the Bastard and his crew.

sp.speaker: Sauoy.
sp.p:
You have a Cæsar of your own Election,
To lead the Vanguard, do but follow me,
I will guide you where the greatest danger dwells:
And like an Emperor fright it from the field:
The Bastards but a Coward, and a Spaniard,
Coward and Spaniard oft-times go together.
Their greatest valour does consist in Braves,
And once repulsed, they will run away like Slaves.

body.stage: Enter Prince Henry, the Bastard, the Duke of Saxon, The Bishop of Mentz, Drum, Cullors, & Soldiours.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
This Land of Germany yields valiant men,
Haughty in heart as they in stature are:
Ten thousand such had I been Leader of
When the Black Prince, lately my greatest Foe,
Opposed me at Mazieres, and won the day,
I had been Lord of that most noble Field,
And where an Hermit now tells over his Beads,
Had sat a Soldier and a Conqueror.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: That Hermit is too bookish to reign long.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
When the Imperial Sceptre fills my hand,
And I have Cæsars wreath upon my brow,
As had my Grandsire, and his royal Father,
I will make Iberia wreak with my foes blood,
And force the Dotard to his Hermitage.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p:
Such thoughts becomes the German Emperor,
Has courage to wage War with all the world.

sp.speaker: Saxon:
sp.p:
Harry, a word in private in your ear,
When you are Emperor, as in time you shall,
I must rule all, although you wear the Crown:
The Edicts I propose you must enact,
And call them your own Laws, not being vexed
At what I do, although I mince your honour.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: How Saxon?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
Harry, Darest thou wreath thy brow,
In any contumelious form gainst me?
It is by my favour that thou art alive.
My greater greatness has repaired thy fame,
And being but my creature, it is fit
I should be known to be the worthier man.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: Between ourselves in private.

sp.speaker: Sax:
sp.p: Publicly, and in the view of all, you will swear.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
I must.
But being installed in the dignity,
I will alter what I swear.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
Come, Come, your Oath,
Being an Elector, I am bard the only Throne,
And therefore will rule by a Deputy.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: This is the Castle, shall we summon it?

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p:
Emperor elect, and princes of the State,
In vain you labour to begirt this hold
With hostile Arms, for Sauoy is in the field,
The Bishop of Cullen, and stout Brandenburgh,
With the Bohemian King, are already pressed,
To give you battle ere you stir your foote.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Are they so brave, so hot, and full of courage?

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
The Palsgraue has breathed spirit into them all.
Though sickness make him droop, we will meet them straight
Battles are governed by the will of Fate.

body.stage: Enter to them Sauoy, Bohem, Marquesse, and Cullen, They are beaten off by the Bastards side, & exeunt.
A Flourish, enter in triumph, Bastard, Saxon, Trier, Mentz, leading the king of Bohemia, Brandenburgh, and Sauoy, Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
So moves the Sun in glory through the sky,
Having outpassed the clouds that shadow him.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
Now Spanish Henry, thou hast proved thyself
Worthy the Germane sceptre, by thy valour,
And he that says not Aue Cæsar, dies.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.p: Swell not too high thou bubble, lest thou break.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: I will break thy heart first.

sp.speaker: Sauoy.
sp.p:
Ere my tongue pronounce
Ave to any that is my enemy;
I will bare my breast to meet thy conquering sword,
And make it crimson with an Emperor's blood.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
There must be but one Emperor, that is ourself,
Therefore to prison with the counterfeit,
Whence neither County Pallatine, nor King,
Shall with their Forces if they were conjoined,
Have power to set thee free.

sp.speaker: Saxon:
sp.p:
For you my Lords, that are Electors like unto myself,
Give but your free consents that he shall govern,
And that shall serve as ransom for you all.

sp.speaker: Marq:
sp.p: Never while life lasts.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.p: Or I breath this air.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p:
Then let them share like fortune in his doom
As they have done this happy day in the field.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: To prison with them all.

sp.speaker: Saxon:
sp.p:
Not till you are Crowned.
That sight shall serve in steed of a Tormentor,
And I rejoice to vex mine enemy.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: Give us our rights.

body.stage: The two Bishops, Ments, & Trier, Crowne the Bastard.

p.foreign: Rex Romanorum, et magnus Imperator Germaniæ.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
Enough those Uiues, take away my life,
In the delicious rapture of my soul,
For there is no heaven methinks like royal thoughts,
The Palsgraues Castles razed unto the ground,
And peace established, we mean once again
To try our Fortune for the Realm of Spain.

body.stage: Enter Peter the Hermit, King of Staine in a disguise.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Since the decease of Englands royal Son,
That placed me lately in Spain's government,
Those that did fear me for his valour sake,
Are by the trains and falsehood of my brother,
Revolted from me, and to save my life
I was constrained to put on this disguise,
To go to England for a new supply
Of men and Soldiers would but weary them.
I have therefore been in France, and failing there,
Am come to Germany, to implore the aid
Of the Electors, but by ill success,
Bohemia, Brandenburgh, and Sauoyes taken:
The Bastard has bewitched the other Peers.
So that my Foe is now an Emperor,
And all the hope I have to get mine own
Lies in the Palsgraue sick I hear to death,
Here I expect his answer to my Letter.

body.stage: Enter the Palsgraue, led in by Cullen, and others.

sp.speaker: Palsgr.
sp.p: Are you the Hermit that did bring this letter?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: And personate him that sent it.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
What Spain's King?
O that I were as I was wont to be,
Before this dangerous sickness was my Foe,
No Christian King that came to me for aid
But he should speed.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: In time you may recover.

sp.speaker: Palsgr.
sp.p:
Mean time be welcome, sit, and take your rest,
And now my Lord of Cullen I am prepared,
To hear the woeful tidings you have brought.
Comes noble Sauoy, and Bohemias King,
With the stout Marquess Brandenburgh in triumph?
And is proud Saxon taken, with the Bastard,
Trier and Mentz made subject to your sword?
O if they be speak it, and make me well.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p:
All is lost, We are conquered, Sauoy is surprised,
And our best Friends in bondage to our Foes:
Heaven has forgot the Justice of our cause.
And only I escaped to tell the news.

sp.speaker: Palsg:
sp.p:
This were enough to kill some man in health,
But in me the effect is contrary.
All lost, all conquered, Sauoy made a Slave:
My Friends in prison, and none escaped but you,
He that can hear such ill news and be sick,
Deserves never to recover, in my blood,
I feel an inflammation of revenge:
There is greater strength gathered into my nerves,
Then ever before, since that I grew infirm:
They will not rest thus, and stay only there,
But having conquered them, assume the Crown,
And make the Bastard Emperor.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: He is Crowned.

sp.speaker: Palsg.
sp.p:
More blood increases, and some more ill news
Would make me cast my Night-cap on the ground,
And call my Groom to fetch me a Warhorse,
That I may ride before an Army royal,
And pluck the Crown from off the Bastards head,
That is another's right.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p:
It is thought my Lord,
Your Castle which you left to save your life
Is beaten to the ground, and your goods theirs:
And further, that they will pursue you hither,
As if you fled before their conquering swords.

sp.speaker: Palsgr.
sp.p:
Be sick who will, mine Ague does retire.
And Cullen thou hast cured me with ill news.
Come valiant Soldiers show yourselves like men,
And be assured we will win the victory.
Hark how they shout as they applauded me:
And see how bravely every Leader rides,
Plumed from the Beaver to the Saddle bow,
Whilst the bold Soldier makes his lofty pike
Stretch in the Air with tossing it aloft.
Bravely done fellow: that trick once again,
And there is gold for thy pains, he fights like Hector.
Whilst at his feet the amazed Grecians fall,
And though Achilles would renew the Field,
He dares not do it, the enemies so strong,
Methinks I hear a peal of Ordinance play,
They are the Bastards Cannons, planted high,
To overthrow my Castle to the ground.
Now they shoot off, Death, all my foes are come.
Marshall my Troops, and let Drum answer Drum.
Myself in person will be general.
But I faint, and am not what I would be.
My spirit is stronger than my feeble limbs,
Lead me once more with grief unto my bed,
Few know the sorrows of a troubled head.

body.stage: Manent Cullen, & Peter. Exit Palsgraue led in.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p:
How fain would valour sickness overcome?
But his infirmity denies such power.
And I am more grieved for his weak estate,
Than for our late great loss.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Palsgraue may help him.
And as I lived a fellow amongst Hermits,
I learnt some skill that has cured many a Prince.
See him safe guarded from his enemies.
And on my life I will recover him.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p:
We are strong enough to waft him to his Fleete,
And when the Enemy shall miss him here,
They will turn their conquering Force another way,
And go for Spain.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: My Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: To subdue it.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Let them proceed, but when he has got his
strength, they will rue their boldness; Mean time trust
to me. For next to Heaven I will cure his malady.

body.stage: Enter olde Fitzwaters, and his Steward. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Old Fitz:
sp.p:
Thou art his hand, the agent of his thoughts,
And only engineer, by which he works
Some dangerous plot to blow his Honour up:
is it possible my Son should be from Court
So often, and the cause unknown to thee,
That art his bosom friend, his Counsellor?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I know no cause except to take the air.

sp.speaker: Old Fyth.
sp.p:
My wrath shall find another in thy breast.
Know that thou treadest on thy last foote of earth,
From whence is no remove, but to the grave:
Fly me thou canst not, and to make resistance,
Will draw upon thee for one Lion's rage,
All the whole den.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
Hold, and I will tell your Honour.
Know that his usual haunt is to the house
Of the Lord Clynton, whither he is gone
To see his Daughter, whom he does affect.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Dotes he on my betrothed, my Love, my wife?
Had he the lives of many hopeful sons
Incorporate with his own, my rage is such
I should destroy them all, ere lose my Love.
But how does she affect him?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
As her life:
Alleging, that the Contract made to you,
Was by constraint to please her honoured Father:
But he was precontracted, first made sure.
And this I heard her speak, with pearled tears;
Then Love, no passion ought to be more free,
Nor any agreement like that sympathy.

sp.speaker: Old Fyth.
sp.p:
I have put on Dianiras poisoned shirt
In the discourse, and every word cleaves to me
As deadly in the apprehension,
As that which killed the Jew-born Hercules.
But wherefore do I combat with myself,
That have a greater enemy to curb?
O, but he is my son! What is a son?
The effect of a sweet minute, he shall dye,
Being my pleasure to effect my pleasure:
Attend me where he is, I may destroy him.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I have a sweet Office, to be Gentleman Porter
to a back door; but it is for a Lady, the best beauty
in England: and if there be any Pandering in the business,
though I am accessory in the fee, because I
live by it, I have no knowledge in the fault. Many
a Courtier would be glad of my place, yet I hold
it not by patent, for term of life, nor for years:
but as young Gentlemen get Venison upon sufferance
or by stealth. If the Lord Clynton should have notice
of this Key or evidence, by which the young
Lord Fythwaters is conveyed to his Daughter against
his will, though she be his Wife by a precontract,
I might be conveyed to the Porters-lodge. But
if all Court-secrets come to light, what will become
of the Farthingales think you that cover
them? No, since Ladies wear Whale-bones, many
have been swallowed, and so may this. Here
comes the Young Lord.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p:
Always at hand, thy carefulness is great:
Where is thy Lady?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Walking in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p:
So early, then I see love is the best lark;
For the Corn builder has not warbled yet
His mornings Carroll to the rising Sun.
There is for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I thank your Lordship. And now like the
Keeper of a prison, having my fee, it is fit I should turn
the Key. You know the way to my Ladies chamber.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Sure liberality was a lover, or he would never
Be so bountiful: some think it a chargeable thing to
keep a Woman of any eminent fashion, and so it is;
but to keep them as I do under lock and key, and
suffer none to enter but such liberal Gentlemen, is
the only way to make a rich Keeper. I must walk
still to watch his coming foorth.

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p: You have been with the Lord Clynton?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
And he promised to meet you in the Garden
covertly.

sp.speaker: O. Fyth.
sp.p: Is this the place?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: And this is the Lady's Page that let us him in.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: O. Fyth.
sp.p:
If you bellow here, you breath your last; by ways,
Back doors, come sir along with me.
If that her father meet, as I desire,
What is but a spark, will prove a mount of fire.
Lock the door after us.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: My Lord I will.

body.stage: Enter in the Garden, Floramell the Lord Clyntons Daughter, and Young Fythwaters.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
The delian Lute is not more Musical
Than thy sweet voice, O my Apollo speak,
That with the rapture of thy words, my soul
May be entranced, and wish no other joys:
That by the discord of two Broken harps,
(Old and unfit for Lovers' harmony)
Our joys should suffer a distate of fear;
And in our most delights a qualm of grief
Run like a vain of Lead through a Gold-mine.

body.stage: Olde Fyth-waters and the Lord Clynton come behinde, and ouer-heare them.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
We grow too jealous of our prosperous days,
Making an evil, where no ill is meant:
Like hallowed ground, love sanctifies this place,
And will not suffer danger to intrude.
Here we are ringed in earthly Paradise,
And may have all the heaven to ourselves:
Be then Mistrust an exile from my breast,
Where lives no jealousy, dwells present rest.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p: But we will disturb it, and your amorous joys.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p: Our Fathers present; Sweet, we are betrayed.

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p:
Betrayed to death: why do you hold my Sword?
There is greater fury kindled in my breast,
Than can be quenched by anything but blood:
I shall turn frantic if you brand the Sea
Of my displeasure in such narrow bounds,
And with a Deluge, equal to the first,
That over-spread the world, swell up so high,
Till not a Mountain overlook the stream,
Nor heaven be seen for Rivers of the Land.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p:
If I could fear the waving of a Sword,
Mine enemies had frighted me ere now;
But I am invaluable, like my mind,
Not to be wounded but with darts of love;
And I as little estimate a Father
In these Pathaires, as he esteems my grief.
There is no priority in love's high Court
Granted unto the Father before the Son;
But like the purest government of all,
Every man's mind is his own Monarchy:
Where reason never set foote to make a law,
Shall common sense keep one, that were absurd.

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p: Wouldst fight with me?

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p:
Not if you will forbeare me;
But in a war defensive I will stand
Against an Army of my Ancestors,
Did their enfranchised souls break ope their tombs,
And reassumed their bodies as they lived,
In their full pride and youthful jollity.

sp.speaker: O. Fy.
sp.p:
Let Ravens perch upon these blossomed trees,
Night Owls their stations in this Garden keep,
And every ominous portents draw near:
For here I will offer unto Hecate,
A hellish sacrifice in a son's blood.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p:
I feel an Earth-quake in my trembling flesh,
And my well boding Genius bids me draw
A sword of vengeance on this hasty Lord,
Ere suffer him to be a parricide.

sp.speaker: O. Fyth.
sp.p: Will the Lord Clynton buckler out my foe?

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p: No, but restrain you from a wilful murther.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
And like the best oblation for your wrath,
Lo, I the subject of this variance fall
Prostrate on my knee, to suffer death,
Ere such a rude act, most un-father-like,
Be put in practise on so good a son.

sp.speaker: O. Fyth.
sp.p: Good to deceive me.

sp.speaker: Y. Eyth.
sp.p: The deceit is yours.

sp.speaker: O. Fyth.
sp.p: Forswear him, and I shall rest satisfied.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: O. Fyth.
sp.p: Give way.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.p: I need no buckler.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p:
I stand not here to offend, but to defend
Your lives and honour gainst so vile an act
Would blur the Conquerors fame perpetually,
Making your swords the furies fire-brands,
Bathed so unnaturally in others blood.
Where neither Honour, nor Religion springs,
It is better far such combats be unfought:
I know your pleas, her father has my grant,
You her affection got against my will:
The place whereon you stand is our own ground,
And here it is fit I abitrate the cause,
Amongst reasonable men peace is held good:
None love dissension, but they thirst for blood.

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p: Counsel prevails, I am glad he is not slain.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p: I live with joy, that I am no Father-killer.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p: Will you subscribe to what we shall enjoin?

sp.speaker: Old Fyth. and Y. Fyt.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p:
In brief it is this. You must forbeare my house,
And never more be seen within my gates.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p: This is extreme.

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p:
I have a heavier doom,
Which on my curse I charge thee to observe:
Which is, That instantly thou leave the Land,
And trouble me no more to get her love.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p: How am I crossed!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: How is my heart tormented!

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p:
Yet I have all the world to traffic in,
Except in England, and your Honour's house:
But as the dissolution of the soul
From such a body as desires to love,
Is burdensome and grievous to the man;
Such is my heart dissevered from my Love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And such is mine to lose thy company.

sp.speaker: Y. Iyt.
sp.p:
You are cruel to impose a curse upon me,
That sentence is extreme, I feel it work.
More deadly on my grieved faculties,
Than to have died upon my fathers sword:
For now mine own woes must destroy myself.
And that is a murther worse than parricide.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: My knife shall end me.

sp.speaker: Old Fyth.
sp.p:
Hold thy desperate hand,
Wouldst make our Nuptials prove a Tragedy?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I would, and be inhumed within the ground,
Rather than measure out a hated bed.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p:
Never regard the passions of a woman,
They are wily creatures, and have learnt this wit,
Where they love most, best to dissemble it.

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p: If that prove so, my heart will be the lighter.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
I have done an act will make me odious
To all succeeding times, betrayed my friend:
But here he comes, I will stay and speak with him.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p:
Careless of foes, of father, or his curse,
Come I again to challenge Floramell,
Which I suspect the Steward has betrayed.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
Within my breast bathe a revengeful sword,
Lo, I oppose it to your greatest wrath:
Yet if you saw the counsels of my heart,
There you may read, it was not I but fear
That was the Author of your love's betraying;
Your angry father threatened me with death,
And I had no evasion but to tell it:
But if your Lordship please to pardon me,
I will lay a plot to help you to your Love.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p: He that is once false, will be never true.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Then wherefore serves repentance?

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p: Well, proceed.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
Set down the place where I shall find your Honour,
And if I bring not thither Floramell,
At our next meeting take away my life.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p: Meet me at Yorke house.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
I will be there ere long.
I have done amiss, and will amend the wrong.

body.stage: Enter old Fythwaters, Clynton, and a Bishoppe.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p:
The Bride not up, and the Archbishop come,
Some call her down.

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p:
Welcome my reverend Lord.
Do not you Bishops use sometimes to dream?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p:
We have the same incitements of the blood
That others have, and in our fantasies
We see strange shapes, and divers things to follow.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p: What was your dream tonight?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p:
As I remember,
Himen was turned into a Mercury,
And he is the Patron of all sly deceits.
But what is my dream to your affairs my Lord?

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p:
That such another dream I had last night:
And if I should be cheated of my Bride,
It were a strange premonition.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p: Fear it not, see where she comes.

body.stage: Enter the Page, drest in one of Floramells Gownes, wearing a Maske.

sp.speaker: O. Fyth.
sp.p: March forwards to the Church.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: So, whilst he takes your place, we are for York House.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I come Fythwaters flying.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Let us away.

sp.speaker: Y. Fy.
sp.p:
The stay of my fair Mistress makes me wild,
Sure I shall never more behold her face;
The Stewards false, and Floramell may change.
I will therefore give a period to my grief,
And in despair finish what life denies:
Yet ere I dye, let all the World this know,
A Woman's love procured my overthrow.

sp.speaker: Y. Fith.
sp.p: My Floramell, to Sea.

body.stage: Enter from Church, old Fythwaters, Clynton, Bishop, and the Page discouered.

sp.speaker: O. Fyth.
sp.p:
O my distracted soul, this is extreme,
Gulled with a Boy, dressed in your Daughters gown:
This is a cross that patience cannot bear.

sp.speaker: Clynton.
sp.p:
Who was the cause of this, speak;
Where is my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Fled to your Son.
The Steward laid the plot; What I have done
Was for my Ladies sake.

sp.speaker: Old Fitzw:
sp.p: That Steward is a Villain.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p:
Let us go seek him.
Take several streets, but let your meeting be
At the Water-side, lest they should flee to Sea.

sp.speaker: Old Fi.
sp.p: To the water side; Lord Bishop keep the boy.

sp.speaker: Bishop.
sp.p:
I will.
My Dream is fallen out right, Hymen is changed
Into a sly deceiving Mercury:
But it is most requisite, they that do wrong
Should feel the penalty by suffering it.
I witness can the Young Lord's precontract,
Bad Fathers that infringe a holy act.

body.stage: Enter King Edward disguised like a priuate man, a Lord with him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
This day I think I promised the Lord Clinton
To be his Guest.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: It was my Liege this Day.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
I have dismissed my Train to steal upon him,
But what is the reason all things are so quiet?
A Lord's house at so great a Ceremony
As is a Marriage, should be like a Court:
Multitudes thronging up and down like waves,
And the Gate kept with an Officious porter,
To give kind entertainment to all Comers;
Here is no such a matter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Here Old Fitzwater: comes.

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p:
Some Pegasus has borne her from my sight
For never a horse I keep can overtake them:
By all conjectures they are gone to Sea,
And Shipped by this.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: His Bride.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Belike it is so.

sp.speaker: O. Fyt.
sp.p:
Some whirlwind follow them;
And making the Ocean rougher than my brow,
Ye dancing Porpoises caper aloft,
And mud the white foam with your jetty backs;
A perfect sign a tempest is at hand.
Rise from the bottom of the deep ye Whales,
And overturn the Ship that carries them:
But let a Dolphin save my Floramell,
And back unto the haven guide her safe.
As for the boy, make him your watery pray,
Eat him alive, that he may hear his bones
Crash in the jaws of the Leviathan:
But save his head for me to know him by,
Author of all my grief and misery.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I will interrupt his passion.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
Stay my Liege.
You shall hear more, here comes the other Father.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p: How now my Lord, have you surprised your Bride?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
I think thy treachery conveyed her hence,
And by thy means another was attired
In her habiliments to vex me thus.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p: You highly wrong me.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
I would right you better,
Were I assured of your close treachery.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p: Threaten me?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: With no more than I will perform.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p: Not in cold blood.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: No, but in blood like fire.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p:
In choler, passion and a crazed brain,
But when you have slept upon your menaces,
You will not then make good a noble challenge,
And enter single combat like a Lord.

sp.speaker: Old Fitz.
sp.p:
There lie my gage I dare thee to the field,
And will aver without the advice of sleep,
That thou wert privy to the Stewards blot.

sp.speaker: Clint.
sp.p: I will take your gage, and meet you when you dare.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
But we will not suffer it, that love the lives
Of every subject, much more of our Peers:
And as for you Fitz-waters, that are grown
Hotter than I expected from your age,
Except you can produce good witnesses,
That Clinton has deceived you of your Bride,
I will stay the combat or imprison you.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: I cannot prove it, but I think it is so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Correct such thoughts, and give him back his gage.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Clinton I am satisfied.

body.stage: Enter a Messenger with a Letter whith he offers to the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How now, what news bring you?

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: Letters my Liege from the Count Palatine

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Our noble friend Bauaria's valiant Duke.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: From him my Liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: We will read them instantly.

All is lost, our elected friend Sauoy taken prisoner,
with him Bohemia, and Bran lenburgh; sickness
would not suffer me to wear Armour, but by the
help of the Royal Hermit, Peter the King of Spain
your friend and Beadsman I am recovered. The Bastard
is made Emperor, and has shipped himself
for Spain, whither I purpose to sail to hinder
His intendments, If I survive the Battle, and be conqueror.
I will unfit you in England, except the Sea be
my Sepulchre.
Your Friend in Arms, ROBERT the Palsgraue.

Ill news, not suddenly to be amended,
The Palsgraues sickness was the greatest loss.
The Bastard Crowned, uncrown him if thou canst,
Thou that art matchless for thy Chivalry.
Send but his head from Spain, to tread upon,
And I should count it an unvalued gift.
As for good Sauoy, and his German Friends,
Ere long I will set them free, or make the soil
That holds them prisoners a Marsh-ground for blood,
Till I hear news from Spain of good success.
Each day I live will be a year of grief.

sp.speaker: Clynton.
sp.p:
Pleaseth my Liege to lay aside your sorrow,
And with your Royal person grace my house,
Clynton will hold it an exceeding favour.

sp.speaker: Old Fitzw:
sp.p:
So will Fitzwaters gracious sovereign.
And though this day look black with my disgrace,
Your Royal presence whites an Ethiop's face.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I accept your kindness, and will be your Guest.

body.stage: Enter the Palsgraue, Cullen: and Peter the King of Spayne, Drum, Cullors, and Soldiors.

sp.speaker: Palsg.
sp.p:
Next unto heaven to you, we give the praise,
Most zealous King for our recovery,
And now my Lord of Cullen show yourself,
As good a Soldier as a Clergy man.
In stead of Beads now use a Martial sword.
For here in Spain where the Black Prince encamped,
And made the Bastard fly, our Tents are pitched,
And the proud Foe comes with a Spleen enraged,
To drive us from Mazieres; Harry shall know,
As he has Kingly blood within his veins,
And is a Cæsar, he shall meet with Cæsars.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: I hear their Drums.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: And I rejoice to hear them,

body.stage: Enter to them the Bastard, Saxon, Mentz, and Trier.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
The Palsgraue here, now we shall have
Your voice to our Election, or for that your life.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: You were sick in Germany.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
But now recovered.
And hither come to beat you out of Spain.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: He bears himself, as he were sure to conquer.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: And looks more like a Jove than like a man.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
I hold my thunder here, and my right arm
Has vigour in it, when you feel my blows
To give you cause to call them Thunderbolts.
If there be any in this Martial Troop
That with a Soldier's face, has a bold heart,
And dates aver that this religious prince
Is not the lawful and true King of Spain,
I will make good his Title by the sword,
And against that proud combatant oppose
Myself as challenger to fight for him.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
I dare take up your gage, and answer you.
But that I should impair this day's renown,
By giving desperate men such means to dye,
Who for you know your Army weak, and few
Would hazard that upon a single fight.
Which in the Battle you are sure to loose,
No Fox-like policy shall blind my sight,
But that I will see the ruin of you all.
This day in the Field, thine Palsgraue and the rest,
He combats well rips up an Army's breast.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: I will answer his proud challenge.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: We forbid it, that are your Emperor, both in style and power:

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
In style, but not in power, that strength is mine,
Except you will be forsworn.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
This for an Oath,
Thou art but the step by which I did ascend,
And being up, rest there till I descend.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: You will answer this anon.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
Here, or elsewhere.
Didst ever know a Cæsar that could fear.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: I will stab the Bastard.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: Worthy Duke desist.

sp.speaker: Palsg:
sp.p: No Combat then will be accepted of.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
In general, with our powers in the open field,
But not betwixt the Generals privately.

sp.speaker: Palsgr:
sp.p:
Then you are Cowards all.
I will so proclaim you in my thundering Drums,
And by the glories that I hope to win,
Prove it this day to thy perpetual shame:
But to a heartless foe words are but vain.
Alarum Drum, that showers of blood may reign.

body.stage: Alarum, The Bastards side beaten off.
Enter in an excrision Bastard, Saxon, Mentz, and Trier.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
It shall be treason to my Fame today,
If I encounter any Foe in the field,
Till I have combated this drunken Saxon.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: How Bastard, how?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
What else?
Thou wert twice misbegotten, once in Nature,
And secondly, in being any pride's default,
By which thou art a Bastard Emperor.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: Stand from about me, or I will strike you dead

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p:
Remember where you are amongst your foes,
Who by your discord may destroy us all.
And this advantage of your variance
Gives them the victory with easiness.
If not for your own Honours and your lives,
Forbeare for ours.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p:
They shall not combat here:
I will make my Rotchet crimson like your Colours,
Ere I stand by and suffer such a wrong.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: How these brave Churchmen talk.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Are you in your Pulpits?

body.stage: Strikes the Bishops on their Targets, and fights with Saxon.
Enter Palsgraue, Peter, and Cullen, with Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: Here is those will strike you.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: What, the Palsgraue come!

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
Emperor be wise, and join thy force to mine,
Till we have driven away the enemy,
And then return to our old variance.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I am Saxons till the Palsgraue dye or fly.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
You should have fought still, it would have been my glory,
To have given aim, and then the conqueror conquered:
But what your variance leaves unfinish here,
I will end with the destruction of you both.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: We fear you not.

body.stage: Charge vpon them, and the Bastard taken Prisoner on the Stage, Saxon and the Bishops beaten off.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.p:
Upon them valiant friends.
Saxon is fled, Cæsar my captive is,
I must not lose him; guard the Emperor sure,
Whilst I pursue the Duke.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: We will.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Am I your prisoner?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Not so good, my slave.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: To trample on, or use as he likes best.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: We are Brothers.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Now: but in your high estate,
No greater enemy than you had I.

sp.speaker: Cul.
sp.p: Best that we guide him to the Palsgraues Tent.

body.stage: Enter Saxon with two swords, and meetes them.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
Although he be Ambitious, and my Foe,
Honour commands me that I rescue him.
That I may have the honour of his death.
When we try Masteries in a single fight.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: It is Saxon, Guard him sure.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: To our best power.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
No further, if you mean to save your lives.
The Palsgraues slain, his blood wreaks on my sword,
And I advise you for your own discharge,
To give this valiant Emperor liberty.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Not whilst we live.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: Help to release yourself.

body.stage: They beate of Cullen the King of Spayne,

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
Most willingly.
Thanks for your pains, but yet we will be Foes.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: To horse, to horse, and talk of that elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: This was the most ill chance that ever happened.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: He said he had slain the Palsgraue.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
It was his cunning to astonish us with fear, but
If he live, how shall we answer him for this mischance.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: See where he comes, I would the storm were past.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
I lost him in the press, his snowy steed
Was crimsoned over with the blood of men,
And Lion-like he fought with all his strength,
But since the Emperor is my prisoner,
I shall the less regard the Dukes escape.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
O Noble Sir, we have deceived your trust,
And lost the Jewel you bad us keep.
Cæsar by Saxon is redeemed and fled,
And we remain in grief for his escape.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
When Fortune is disposed to cross a man.
Valour and foresight are of no effect:
Released by Saxon, and his Keepers live;
You are not as I thought you, valiant men:
But worse than these that run away for fear.
He should have made passage through my heart,
Ere scaped from me by Soxon or his plots:
But now it is too late to follow him;
And the whole Field is made a liquid Sea,
Sink may they both into the crimson fen.
But why should they sink, you deserve it best:
From henceforth I will never take a Spaniards part,
Except he had a far more valiant heart.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Let my blood speak for me; fair words displease.

sp.speaker: Palsg.
sp.p:
Well, since I think it was weakness and not will,
By which they are escaped, I calm my spleen,
And rest content that we have won the field.
After you are establish in your Throne,
I will sail to England to re-greet the King:
And then to Germany, where if we meet
Bauaria's, air shall be his winding-sheet.
Retreat, retreat, and thank heaven for the day.

body.stage: Enter Bastard, Saxon, Mentz, and Trier.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
At your requests my Lords, I am contented
To receive this Emperor into grace and favour.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
He flouts me; would you have me suffer this?
At their requests they have requested me
To allay my spleen, and take thee into favour.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: They will never be friends.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: Let us leave them both to fight.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: We will force you else.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: We are a going:

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
So, now I will imagine that this ground
Is all the Empire that my greatness sways:
And that the heads of many rebel Subjects
Are placed on thee; that striking off thy head,
I cut off half a Nation at a blow.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
And I the Emperors of a Nation.
Why dost not kill me, since it is in thy power?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Thou savedest my life, for that I will set thee free.

sp.speaker: Sax.
Bast.
sp.p: Such be my conquests over those I love.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: So, they are friends, they have fought away their anger.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: Has conquered me with courtesy and valour.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Then now to counsel how we shall proceed
In this most dangerous war against the Palsgraue,
Who as I hear by firm intelligence.
Means with his Fleete to touch the English Shore,
And draw the valiant Edward to his part.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
If such a day come, it will be black to us:
For of all Nations in the world, I hate
To deal with Englishmen, they conquer so.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
Follow his example, and let us get a King
To take our part, as well as they have done:
France has been wasted by their cruelty,
And cannot but in spleen desire revenge,
Were he solicited to be our friend,
We should with the more ease be conquerors.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: Send thither.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: Or sail thither.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
That is the best:
But shall we only build our hopes on strength;
I think it were good to piece the Lion's skin
Where it too short falls, with the Foxes skin,
A couple of Protean villains I have ready,
For any dangerous attempt in peace,
And they can poison, stab, and lie in wait
Like Serpents, to entrap and cease their prey,
Mendoza and Uandome, those are the men:
Let them be called in.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: They are here, great Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Most mighty Emperor, what is your Highness' will?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
That unto England presently you sail,
And there consort you with the Earl of Artoyes,
A Frenchman born, but one that loves us well;
Let him and you send us intelligence
Of the proceedings of the English King,
With the haughty Palsgraue, give the Earl this Letter,
By which ye may win credit in his trust:
And ere it be long I will devise a plot,
Which you shall manage, for the general good.
Be careful, as you do respect our love,
And hope for gold in showers; mean time take this.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Your will shall be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
Great Jove can say no more:
That State thrives best that has such Slaves in store.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
See our Fleet ready: and ye swelling gales,
That blow the good hours, fill our empty sails.

body.stage: Enter the King the Queene, and Poytieres.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
My Lord of Poytieres, as you are informed,
Where means the Emperor and his train to land?

sp.speaker: Poyt.
sp.p:
Here at this town of Bulleigne, and the news
Is certain that his Mightiness is near.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
How angry has the heavens been with the sea,
That it hath boiled so much, and cast the sands
Into such mountains that they overlook
The bounds that held them in.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
Well may our friends
Escape the danger of this heavy storm:
Small gusts at Land, sink a whole Fleete at Sea;
And whilst our Cities keep us from their rage,
The Rocks beat them, as Tennis-Courts do balls.
I would have an Atheist travel through the deep,
And he shall see such wonders, that his soul
Would make him soon believe there is a God.
But what fair Gentlewoman have we here,
Which is a Shipwrecked creature, comes a shore?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
All wet and weary with a boisterous storm,
At last I have set my foote upon the Land;
I tremble as a Fever shook my joints,
But it is the Ocean that has frozen me:
Drop there thou moisture of a swelling Flood.
And let me see, no Fisher-man at hand,
To tell me in what Coast I am arrived:
Alas I see none, I shall dye with cold.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Poytiers speak to her, give the woman comfort.

sp.speaker: Poyt.
sp.p: How is it with pretty Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Sir, I am very cold, and wet, and ill,
Would you could help me to a little fire
To dry myself, and I would pray for you.

sp.speaker: Poyt.
sp.p:
It is now no time to reason of your state:
Here take my Cloak.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
Alas Sir, it is but thin,
And makes me shake the more to think upon it:
I would be shifted into warmer Robes,
If I could meet with some kind Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Make use of me, you shall not want for help.

sp.speaker: Flo.
F. King.
sp.p: Thy state wants present pity, women take it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I have seen a King ere now,
And by your Diadem you should be one:
Pray, rather let me dye than trouble you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
It is perfect charity to help the poor:
Yet by these Jewels, you should bear a place,
If not amongst the Royal, with the Noble.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
Indeed I am but a poor Gentlewoman,
Punished for wearing Jewels in a storm:
But I have lost a husband whom I loved,
For marrying whom, I have endured this cross;
And now his friends, if they should find me out,
Would finish what the storm has left undone.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
It was Infortunio, as mine is,
With the alteration of a letter only.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p:
Good Infortuna go along with me,
I will find some help for this thy misery.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
May the Sea never use you of this fashion;
I take your courtesy, and will attend.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Young, fair, and lovely, is she not Poytiers?

sp.speaker: Poyt.
sp.p: She is a comely, and a sweet Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
In my opinion she is the fairest creature
Nature ever made.

sp.speaker: Poyt.
sp.p: In love my gracious Liege?

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: What and my Queen alive, that would seem strange.

sp.speaker: Poyt.
sp.p: Love does regard no person, nor the time.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Love is a power will over-rule a King.

sp.speaker: Poyt.
sp.p:
Finding her honest, though of mean estate,
You may do well to raise poor virtue up,
And marry her to some great Nobleman.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: I will think of that hereafter: now, the news?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: The Emperor and the Electors are arrived.

body.stage: Enter Bastard, Saxon, Mentz, and Trier.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Health to the Majesty and Seat of France.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
As welcome hither is your Mightiness,
As if you were arrived in Germany.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: I thank King Iohn.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Saxon, with Mentz, and Trier.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: We rest your loving friend for War.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: For Counsel.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: And Counsel is as great a friend as War.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: It hath prevailed as much.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: Thrice welcome all.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
The storm has kept us overlong at Sea:
But Mighty King of France, worse storms than these
Have and will shake us, if you help us not:
All things go Backwards, that should bode us good;
And he that is Conqueror already,
The haughty Palsgraue, is to England sailed,
To join with Edward in our overthrow.

sp.speaker: F. Ki.
sp.p:
We have felt the valour of the English King,
And of his son, the Black Prince now deceased:
Witness Poytiers and Cressey, where our blood
Royal, although it be saved to make clay
Moist with the showers, and temper the dry earth:
When I and all my sons were prisoners taken,
And had to England to be wondered at:
Ransomed although I was, it grieves me much
I cannot do the like unto my foe.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
Let your French Soldiers join themselves with ours,
And we will invade his Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: And constrain him and the Palsgraue to the like disgrace.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p:
Fortune was never steadfast unto any.
But like the Ocean that bounds in the Land,
Both ebbs and flowes according to the Moon.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p:
But if I might advise your Majesty,
By former losses you should be more wise,
Than hazard France again to the like spoil:
Edward is fortunate in all his wars;
And wise men will not strive against the stream:
Therefore be circumspect, and keep your own.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
This theme our counsel shall at large discuss,
Till when, to England we will Embassage send,
To advise King Edward not to be our foe,
Lest it offend us, that are friends to both:
If the Dove speed not, we will the Serpent prove.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
And win by craft, what may not be by love.
Who shall have that employment?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Not your Honour, because your spirit is rough and turbulent.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
No, if I might entreat these reverend Bishops,
By them I would direct this Embassy:
Since it concerns them, it behoves they stir,
Who know the sweets, will cause no war.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: We will undertake it, if the Emperor please.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
When I send thither, it shall be in thunder:
Yet as the French King orders it proceed.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
You know your charge, be mild, but yet not base,
Though we give ground, we will not lose our place.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
Even now a bold conceit hath entered me,
And that is to visit England in disguise:
As well to further our conspiracy
Against the Palsgraue and King Edwards life,
As to survey the Country, and observe
What Haven is best to entertain a Fleete:
The English Nation with my soul I hate,
And would do anything to win the State.

body.stage: Enter Edward, Clynton, olde Fytzwaters, the Palsgraue, Cullen, and others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Not possible my Lords to find those men?
Are they so wily to deceive us all?
Sure they are harboured by some near about,
That does affect the English Diadem:
He is worse than mad would aim at Englands Crown.
Though the Black Prince be dead, so many sons
I have left to govern, which mars their rule.
Edward himself has left a hopeful heir,
The Princely Richard to inherit it.
Plots yet, tricks yet, well we must hope the best.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.p:
I rather think the ill was aimed at me,
Because I came to move your Majesty
For the deposing of the Emperor:
And it is known the Bastard is my foe,
Witness the Wars in Germany and Spain:
Treason by him is evermore in act,
His brain coins faster than the English Mint;
Treacherous proceedings, gold has many friends:
And he must be a man of excellent virtue
Whom it corrupts not. Howsoever, I am sorry
The Sailors did escape.

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p:
Here are their cases.
Under the which I think were better clothes,
And for their Steeds, thought could not be more quick,
Or we had took them.

sp.speaker: O. Fytz.
sp.p: They were swift indeed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
As swiftly with their flight vanish our fears.
And now most Noble Palsgraue of the Rhine,
Think yourself welcome to the English Court:
And reverend Cullen.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: I do thank your Grace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Your Father loved me well, and for his sake,
As well as for your own, I will honour you:
And after feasting we will try your force
In friendly manner at a Tournament,
Which as I think, you have prepared my Lords.

sp.speaker: O. F.
sp.p:
We have my Liege, and the most youthful blood
That the Court yields will show their Chivalry,
In honour of Bauaria's Royal Duke.

sp.speaker: Palsg.
sp.p:
Let him sit fast that shall contend with me,
Or I shall shake him, be he never so Royal:
I show no favour when I am in Arms,
Nor look for any from my Opposites.
But Tournaments are revels made for sport,
And he runs well, that gets a good report.

sp.speaker: King:
sp.p:
We will try your valour, and perchance run with you.
Lead on.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p:
The discontented English like to me,
Hates all delight, Aye and the Court itself:
To lead a private life, where they may plot
Revenge on those that are their opposites:
Not many years past, who but I esteemed,
King Edward has upon my shoulder leaned,
And thanked me in mine ear many a time,
For making France his, I betrayed Ualoys
My sovereign King, in England to get grace:
And now I looked to be a Duke at least:
Artoise is slighted as a thing forgot,
But I have sent my Attendant to the Court,
And if he speed not, I shall prove as false
Edward to thee, as to my Native French.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.p:
The King is not at leisure
To listen to your suit; All his thoughts now
Are taken up to give the Palsgraue grace,
Who is come to Court, and means to Tourney there

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p:
Treason run with them, or some dangerous plot,
Take life and being to destroy them both;
Must my affairs give place unto a Palsgraue?
It was I that quartered with the English Lions,
The Arms of France, in opening Edwards Title,
Which but for me had in oblivion slept,
Then I was as the Palsgraue in his breast,
My sight his food, my saying, his heart's rest.
Who is that, that knocks, look forth, and bring us word?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: A couple of Gentlemen would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Arto.
sp.p:
Let them come in, were they a pair of mischiefs,
They are welcome now. For I have thoughts like Hell,
black and confused.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: These are the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Uandome.
sp.p:
Our business is to you most noble Artoise,
The Emperor does salute you in this Letter,
And prays you by the Honour of an Earl,
You fail not to conjoin your aid with ours,
About some plot against his Enemies.

sp.speaker: Arto.
sp.p: The Letter speaks the words, but names no plot.

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.p:
It is not devised as yet, but ere long great Cæsar.
Will set it down, and send it to us all.
Now was his Mightiness desires is this,
That you give shelter to us while we stay
For his Affairs in England, and your pension
Which every year you have received from him,
Shall from henceforth be doubled with his love.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p:
Cæsar is gracious, and has my heart:
But were not you the Servants that attended
On the last Emperor that was made away,
And helped to send him to a timeless grave?

sp.speaker: Uandome.
sp.p: We were my Lord.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p: Let me embrace you in mine arms for that.

sp.speaker: Mendo:
sp.p:
But that ill speed followed our hopes today,
We had given a period to King Edwards life,
And to the Palsgraues.

sp.speaker: Uandome.
sp.p:
We attempted it.
Habited like Sailors, but our pistols failed,
And after long pursuit, our Robes thrown off,
We escaped with life.

sp.speaker: Mendozze.
sp.p: And come to live with you.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p:
Live here as safe as in a Fort of brass.
Such men I wished for to assist my spleen,
Unto one mark all our affections tend.
And they both dye if that the Emperor send.

body.stage: The Trumpets sound within as at a Tournament:

sp.speaker: O. Fytz.
sp.p:
Did you ever see a better Tournament,
Or braver Runners than this day appeared
In the Tilt-yard?

sp.speaker: Clyn.
sp.p:
The best that ever I saw.
What a brave Horse the Palsgraue rid upon,
And with what courage, nimbleness, and strength,
Did he unhorse his valiant opposites?
Spears flew in splinters, half the way to heaven,
And none that ran against him kept his saddle,
Except the King, and he demeaned him well:
It joys my soul, that he has yet in store
Such manly vigour; and the peoples hearts
Were not a little glad.

sp.speaker: O. Fytz.
sp.p: Here they come all.

body.stage: Enter King Edward, Palsgraue, Cullen, and others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
I fear you are over-wearied with our sports,
To speak the truth, I feel them troublesome,
Whether it be by discontinuance or age, I know not,
But my breath grows short.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.p:
What Oak is ever strong? age makes Jove's tree,
The fairest King, and Emperor of the wood,
To bend itself, and bow his lofty arms
Downwards unto the earth that fostered it.
No Cæder grows straight till his latest day:
As there is a weakness in their springing up,
So is there in their declination.
The middle age the lusty does express,
And there flowes vigour, like a sea of strength,
Able to bear down what doth stand the stream:
Such is mine now; but as my years do flow,
Like Oaks and Cæders they must straight bow low.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Sit by our side, and wear a Cæsars wreath.

sp.speaker: Palsgr.
sp.p:
Victorious Edward keep it as your right,
And let it mingle with your Royal Crown,
That have deserved it in a field of war,
Not as it is mine, given for a Tournament.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
It is our gift, and you shall wear it still,
Bring forth the other honour we intend
Unto this thrice renowned Gentleman.

body.stage: Enter an Herauld, with a faire Cushion, and the Garter vppon it.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.p: My gracious Liege here is the Garter ready.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Which to the Palsgraue we command you bear,
Garter and Herald here presents your Honour
With the Order of the Garter, whence he takes
His Office and his Name, by our Decree:
This is a favour which no Foreign Prince
Ever enjoyed yet, but the time may come
When Kings in seeking it may be installed,
It was my Institution, and is worn
By none but the most Noble, and those few
Hereafter I will tell your Excellence
The Motive why the Order was devised:
Mean time his hand shall clasp it to your Leg,
For it is a custom which you must not break.

sp.speaker: Palsgr:
sp.p: Your Highness honours me exceedingly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
You are now my Fellow-Knight, and you must swear,
To fight for Ladies, and their Fames preserve.
But that we leave to Deputation,
It shall suffice now, say on, pass your word.
My Word and Oath, so please your Majesty,
The Motto, as I red it was in French,
Honny soit qui Mal y pense:
Ill be his meed makes goodness an offence:
Or, Evil be to him that evil thinks.
I have learnt the sense, the Order I will keep
Inviolate, by Hand and by my Sword;
And hope in time it shall as famous prove,
As that of Malta or Ierusalems.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p:
The Bishops, Mentz, and Trier, sent from France,
By the French King desire to be admitted.
With them associate comes the bold Poytiers,
But as I think he is no Ambassador.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Give them admittance.
We could not wish for a more brave assembly,
Than at this instant to give Audience.

body.stage: Enter Mentz and Trier, and Saxon disguised like a Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p:
Because the matter does concern ourselves
Most mighty King of England, we have taken
This Embassy in hand, not sent by Cæsar,
But from your Neighbour, the great King of France:
Who by us first entreats, after enjoins
You take good heed how you the Palsgraue aid,
For that he says, and will maintain as much,
It were unjust now Cæsar to depose,
Who by his valour, if all Titles fail,
Merits the honour of an Emperor.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p:
And that he is peerless for his mind,
And haughty resolution through the world,
That none so well as he deserves the style,
And being invested in the dignity,
It were a dishonour great and Capital,
Now to constrain him to a lower place:
Which if you seek, he will shield from such disgrace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Has France forgot our former victories,
That his Commission is so peremptory?
Or is it but the Stratagem of Cæsar,
To blind us with the Name of the French King?
And Iohn of France be ignorant of this,
Before we answer your proud Embassy,
We will send Ambassadors to know the truth:
And if we be deceived by a trick,
Cæsar shall know he has dishonoured us.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
I am a Frenchman, and a Peer of France,
My name Poyctiers, but no Ambassador.
Yet by the Honours that my sword hath won,
King Iohn of France delivered what they spake.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Being no Ambassador, why came you hither
To be a Spy, and to survey my Land?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
A Spy, one of my blood without disguise,
Being the first Revealer of myself.
How can this hold King Edward to be true?
I use no Intelligence but with my sword:
Nor seek for other corners than deep wounds.
So if I come by any great man's heart
In honourable difference I survey it.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
At whose heart aim you now, that you are come?
To justify an Embassage against me?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
I say who wears the German Diadem
Deserves it better than the best that is here;
Or any whom the English King, or thou
For private reasons wouldst prefer to wear it,
And that it is not honour prompts you to it;
But secret pride, to have a person govern,
Which Palsgraue, thou mightst rule ambitiously.

sp.speaker: Palsgr:
sp.p:
Thou fowl-mouthed slanderer eat thy proud words up,
Wherewith thou hast aspersed me; or my fury
Shall make thee curse this bold-faced impudence.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: Come, Come, you cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p: Cannot.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
Nor dare. I will stand the fury of thy proudest shock,
Not fearing danger in so sleight a Foe:
Should I put off these Masks, my wounds would fright,
And these wide mouths which I have got in war
Not half healed up, pronounce it in thy blood.
Thou art too weak to enter Arms with me.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
Since mildness cannot temper your stern wrath,
But that your spleen must vomit upon me.
I will teach you Sir to have your tongue locked up.
By taking off your lock.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: My hair torn off.

sp.speaker: Palfgr.
sp.p: Who have we here? This is the haughty Saxon.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: Grant me the combat Edward, of this Palsgraue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: He is a prince himself, and knows his power.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
Now by the honour of my Fathers house,
Saxon I will meet thee in the Realm of France,
In the Kings Court, or place where thou wert born,
So I may have good Hostage, and fair play.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: Now by my gage thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Palsgr:
sp.p:
This shall suffice.
I have your lock to me a better pledge.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
I would I had thy head to countervail it.
A whirl-wind be thy guide, and a rough Sea
Plague thee before thou comest for my hair's loss,
Hell and some Devil was author of this cross

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
You have paid him soundly and deservedly.
But now to answer you in brief, it is thus,
The Palsgraue and ourself will see the King
With expedition, where (if he make good
The proud Injunction you have charged us with,
We will lay wast his Country, and once more
Put France in hazard of a sound loss.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
This Saxons brave, gives courage to us all.
But I will requite it with a German brawl.

body.stage: Enter Saxon, Artoise, Uandome, and Mendoza, Trier, and Cullen.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
You are the cause next to disgrace the Palsgraue
For which I came. The Emperor greets you well,
And would have noble Artoise lend his hand,
Both to cut off Bauaria and the King.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: Here in England.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: Or what place you will.

sp.speaker: Uandome.
sp.p: France is the safer for the Stratagem.

sp.speaker: Mendoz.
sp.p: And Edward is determined to sail thither.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
In France then give it birth.
Where if it fail I will be the Palsgraues death.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
The care of Kingdoms is a weighty charge
So is the care of children. But Love's care
Exceeds them all: That dries the blood of life
More than the Fever, though they burn like Fire:
And to submit it to the law of reason,
Makes reason folly, and discourse a Fool.
Then irresistible all ruling power
Revel in young men's hearts, and leave the old,
Or meddle with inferiors, not with Kings;
We should be privileged, because most high,
But what is a King unto a Deity?

body.stage: Enter Floramell, with a Napkin, and a cup of Wine.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p: Your Majesty called for a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
I did fair creature, and I thank your pains.
But when I view the colour of your lip.
And look on this, the wine methinks looks pale:
You have a better luster in your eye,
Than any sparkle that can rise from hence:
The silver whiteness that adorns thy neck,
Sullies the plate, and makes the Napkin black.
Thy looking well, makes all things else look foul,
Being so fair in body, what is thy soul?

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p:
My soul and body are the gift of heave,
And I will use them to my Makers praise:
If other service (great King) you require,
I am ready, attend your hearts desire.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
I think sweet creature, what thy tongue has uttered
Is distant many paces from thy heart.
My hearts desire, it is not in bending low,
After the officious custom of a Court:
Nor lies it in the use of common things,
To bring and take away; my hearts desire
Is to enjoy thee in another sort,
Which if thou yield unto, thou shalt be great,
Greatest in France, next, nay before my Queen:
For I will find means to to take away her life,
So I may have thee as a second wife.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
The Saint of France forbid it, and all powers,
That have continued both so long together
In sacred rites of Marriage, heaven deny
I should be Author of her Tragedy:
Or give content where murther is opposed.
If I should yield, and your Queen made away,
Might you not use me so another day?
It is fearful building upon any sin,
One mischief entered, brings another in:
The second pulls a third, the third draws more,
And they for all the rest set ope the door:
Till custom take away the judging sense,
That to offend we think it no offence.
Wherefore my Lord, kill mischief while it is small,
So by degrees you may destroy it all.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Divine is thy discourse, like to thy beauty.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
Do not Idolatrise, beauty is a flower,
Which springs and withers almost in an hour:
Sickness impairs it, but death kills it quite,
It fades as fast as shadows in the night.
Why should your Grace call it Divinity?
There is naught divine, but that which cannot dye.
Lest I offend by staying here too long,
I will take my leave, and so curb in my tongue.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Speak still, I will hear thee.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
To our Sex it is bard,
We should be twice seen, ere we be once heard.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
She will never yield! why do I woo her then?
Because I cannot bridle my desires,
Nor sleep, nor eat, but as I dream of her:
She is to me as my Genius, or my soul;
And more than they, because she governs them.
Some way I will take, my freedom to recover:
That there is no physic made to cure a Lover!

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: My Love.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: How! Infortuna?

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
I mistook thy name:
Yet now I think of it, I had busy thoughts
How I might raise that Virgin to some Honour,
And match her with some worthy Peer of France.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: yourself my Lord in some Adulterate kind.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
Nay then you wrong me, I meant virtuously;
Believe me Sweet I did, I love thee so,
No evil thought should make me wrong thy bed,
By this it shall not, this, and this, my Love.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: You flatter me.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
I love thee as I should:
What, we have lived together twenty years,
And never wrong each other, should I now
Be the first causer of the marriage breach?
Banish such thoughts, let all mistrust begone.
If she grow jealous, I am twice undone.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p:
I will have about with her, to find out all:
Within there.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
What Medea was it,
Of whom you learnt the Art of Sorcery,
To enchant a King, and draw him to your bed?
Think you, because you are my Maid of Honour,
I will honour you so far, to have my Lord,
Thou shameless Callet? it is ingratitude,
Into my Husbands heart so to intrude.
I could have helped thee to a wealthy choice,
Had you spared mine; but now it cannot be,
For I must hate thee for thy treachery.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I am accused, that ought to be excused,
And blamed as one unchaste, for being chaste.
I Enchant the King, and use Medea's Art?
Witch-craft I have always hated with my heart:
And except Modesty a Circe be,
I know no other kind of Sorcery.
Your Highness sent me with a Cup of Wine
Unto the King, the occasion of his wooing;
Was it my fault to do your Highness will?
Judge gracious Majesty but as you ought,
And do not blame me for a Virgins trial:
His love was answered with a strong denial;
And so denied for ever shall he be,
That seeks by such means to dishonour me.
Before I wrong a Queen so truly kind,
I will mar my face, and make my sad eyes blind.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
In.
We will consider farther of your tears:
I will have her watched, if she proves false, she dies;
But if continue constant to the end,
Never had Lady a more Royal friend.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
Since I was cast upon this fatal Rock,
And saw my Love dissevered by the waves,
And my kind Steward in the Ocean drowned,
Here I have lived, fed only with raw Fish,
Such as the Sea yields: and each Ship I see,
(As daily there are some furrow this way)
I call unto for aid, but never the never.
Once asked me, What I was? I answered him,
An Englishman. Quoth he, Stay there and starve.
To the next that past, I said I was a French-born.
I will aid no French quoth he. Unto a third,
That I a Spaniard was. He bad me hang:
So that I know not what I ought to say,
Nor whom to speak to: but in happy time,
From this high Rock, I see a tall Ship come,
Furnished with all his Sails; and as it ploughs
The Ocean up, it raises hills of snow,
That fly on both sides as they did give way,
To make a valley for the Ship to pass.
Their Captain as I think looks upon me,
And has took notice of my waving hand.
Now the Ship turns and this way ploughs amain,
As if it meant to run itself aground:
In happy time, now I shall be relieved.

body.stage: Enter Saxon, Artoise, Mentz, Uandome, and Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
It was hereabouts the Gallant beckoned me,
He seems a person of some eminence,
By the glittering of his Suite against the Sun,
Cast Anchor here, and let us question him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Yonder he stands, mounted upon the rock.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
The very same. What art thou, what is thy name?
Thy place of birth, fortune, and parentage,
That thou art left upon this desolate shore?
And what requirest thou stranger at our hands?

sp.speaker: Y. Eytz.
sp.p:
As you are men, and are therefore may be crossed,
Be favourable to a wretched man:
Know, that the Sea has cast me on this place,
Where I have led a discontented life,
Ever since the last storm, and no passenger
Has taken pity to remove me hence.
Though food I want not, cause the sea yields fish,
I would be shifted to a better place.
My name is Fitzwaters, by my birth a Lord:
My natural residence in England was,
Some of your company I have often seen;
Set me aland where dwell inhabitants,
And thankfully I will requite your love.

sp.speaker: Artoy.
sp.p: It is young Fytzwaters, pray sir take him in.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
You know my hatred to all Englishmen,
Since my disgrace; and shall I pity him?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: But he is descended of a Noble house.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: The more should I rejoice to see him dye.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: Has valour.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: Let him use it on the Rocks.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p:
But every enemy bears not your mind,
Some have been favourable to their foes.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
And it is an honour in an enemy
To save where he may kill.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p: Your answer there?

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: You speak as you would compel it.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
In the honourable intercourse of men
I should do so, and were you in my case,
You would enforce your own necessity.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
What would this Stranger be in prosperous state,
That bears so high a mind in his distress?

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p: I would be as thou art, proud of nothing.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: Is a Ship nothing?

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
As it anchors here
It bears a goodly show; but launched again,
And a storm rise, it may be cast a land
As I have been: nay worse, it may may be sunk,
And then what is it, but a fair something, nothing?
What is, and now is not; man's life, or a dream,
Now swimming, and then swallowed in the stream.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
His words are piercing, some go take him in:
Come down, and be received into our Boat.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That shall be my charge.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
Could we draw this spirit
Into our plot, he would help to manage it
Unto the life, and I should take it better
Than yet I do.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Persuasion may corrupt.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: But be advised how you persuade him to it.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: And take his Oath at first for sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p:
We are no puny Politicians,
To be instructed in the rules of evil:
Here comes Fitzwaters.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: Your hand.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p: And sword, but that the Sea devoured it.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
Know sir, we have business of import in hand,
Wherein our purpose is to crave your aid,
And as we sail to France we will open it.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyt.
sp.p: I am yours in all things that are honourable.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
Honourable or not, you shall do what we list.
Launch foorth into the deep.

body.stage: Enter King Edward, Palsgraue, old Fytzwaters, Clynton and Cullen, Drummes, Colours, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
We did not think to have footed the French ground
A second time in such Hostility;
But when the conquered bears so proud a head,
It is fit we make him stoop: yet lest the King
Be not himself, or be abused by any,
My Lord of Cullen, we entreat your pains
To enquire it out by our Ambassador,
As Mentz and Trier his: say that our force
Might spoil his country, and make waste his land;
But that with French blood we have surfeited,
And therefore care not greatly to shed more.
Say, We will meet him at an interview,
There to discourse our griefs before we fight,
Where if he have wronged me, he shall do me right.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: I shall delate your Highness Embassy.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p:
But say from me my sword never drunk French
And therefore it is thirsty for their lives:
That ere I leave the Continent of France,
Without good satisfaction from the King,
None of his Cavaliers shall wear a lock,
I will have them all cut off, and every year
Be paid in such a tribute for my wrongs.
As for proud Saxon, Say my word is kept,
And bid him warily respect his own:
The French Kings Palace shall not save his life,
Nor the best rampiered Bulwark in the Land,
Except he answer me as fits a Peer.

sp.speaker: Cul.
sp.p: But to the Emperor, what is your will to him?

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.p:
That as he run from Spain, he shall run hence,
Or I shall make him a poor Emperor.
His Bastard bravery tell him must go down,
And the legitimate wear Cæsars Crown.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Fail not to utter every syllable
Both of the Palsgraues sending and our own.

sp.speaker: Cul.
sp.p: I shall deliver both.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.p:
Take it how they please,
If they fly hence, we will follow through the Seas.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: I go.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
High is this Embassy, like to your valour,
Which I admire, and love ardently;
That I could wish your presence all my days,
And think your company to me more sweet
Than mine own Kingdom, or my Crown besides.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.p: Your love and Royal presence I desire.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p:
Clynton, and bold Fytzwaters, be it your charge,
Provided well of our best Ships and Soldiers,
To sail to Germany, and free our friends,
Kept as we hear there with a slender guard,
In a weak Castle.

sp.speaker: Old Fitz.
sp.p: Which we will soon beat down.

sp.speaker: Palsgr.
sp.p: And bring them hither.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: Or return no more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: March forwards to the place where ,we will encamp.

body.stage: Enter Fitz-waters, Artoyse, Uandome, and Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p:
What should the reason be of this dissension
And why is young Fitz-waters froward thus?

sp.speaker: Artoyse.
sp.p: His arguments are strong and forcible.

sp.speaker: Mendoz.
sp.p:
Single us hither to the forest side,
Under pretence to plot more privately,
And now not only to mislike our drifts,
But call us punies, and unskilful men,
It shows a spleenful hatred to us all.

sp.speaker: Y. Eytz.
sp.p:
Not unto all, but only to you two:
Why should the Earl and I born a Lords son,
Join with a pair of base companions,
In such a weighty cause as a Kings death:
I know you will say you have been physicians,
Sailor, and Soldiers, and in such disguise,
Done some exploit that have deserved respect,
I grant as much, but yet your births are mean.
No gentry in your blood was ever known
By natural Heraldry, your low descents
Disables us, and we must seek to rise,
With others of our own condition.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Come Uandome, of ourselves we will do the deed

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.p:
That were the engrossing of the same from us
And so you would have all the thanks yourselves:
Neither commixed with us, nor yet alone,
Shall it be acted, but as we are the best
In birth, and ability to do it,
We will have the privilege of doing it.

sp.speaker: Vandome.
sp.p: And we should give it over.

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.p:
To your betters.
Or having fit place, Artoise and myself,
Will kill you first, then cast you in the River.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p: He speaks what we intend.

sp.speaker: Mendozze.
sp.p:
Intend your worse?
Cæsar has promised him the Palsgraues place,
And I shall be the Marquess Brandenburgh:
Think you such Titles shall be lost by fear.
Our valour has been tried with worthy men,
And ere we lose the glory of the Act,
Uandome and I do mean to use you so.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.p: They will never be honest.

sp.speaker: Uandome.
sp.p: Come Sir, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p: Most resolute villains, how they would outbrave us?

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.p:
But noble Artoise, now the fire is given
The Cannon must go off.

body.stage: Fight. Y. Fyth and Artoise kill Uandome, and Mendozza.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p:
Unto their deaths.
So they are dead, and now the Fame remains
Only to us, that will accomplish it.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.p:
Only to me, that will perform it alone.
Thinks Artoise those were slain cause they are base?
Or that I wrought you to assist my plot,
Because you are of the Nobility?
