No, I have still this Maxim in my thoughts,
That a Competitor, though never so Noble,
Takes away half the fame in everything:
I could have opened this unto you all,
But that I thought myself too weak for three:
And therefore providently used thy strength,
To kill them first, that I might slay thee after.
Now they are dead, thy life must follow theirs,
And so I share the honour to myself:
I will be Palsgraue, Marquess Brandenburgh,
And the Bohemian King in me alone,
Cæsar shall write himself three Friends in one.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p: I do not think thou meanest to be a traitor.

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.p:
Now you come near me, but that secrets mine,
And seeking it you must dig through my heart,
Or it will never be found, it lies so close.

sp.speaker: Art:
sp.p: I will know it, or a reason in your blood.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz:
sp.p: Wilt thou turn honest?

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.p:
Do not torture me,
With repetition of that Beggars name:
Whom none but Idiots, Innocents, or blocks
Will entertain.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
I would change your mind
From this erroneous and ill boding thought,
Because of late you freed me from the rock,
But if it be so hurtful to your sight
Be your own death, I will not reveal my mind.

sp.speaker: Arto.
sp.p:
If that I cannot force it with my sword,
I will let it alone.

So lie together, three a pair Royal makes,
And here is a pair Royal of excellent Villains;
These have slain princes by their own confession,
These made a Nation swim in her own blood,
The stream is turned with you, it is now high flood:
But I must cast you all into the River.
Yea, swords and all, to clear me from suspect;
Suspect? by whom this place yields no such eye,
It is well the world is rid of their villainy.

body.stage: Enter seuerally, the French king and Floramell.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: His Highness here, then Floramell give back.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
It is she, a word; there is no retiring hence.
In vain you strive, my force opposed against yours,
Will easily subdue your woman's strength,
But there is a power included in your eye
That conquers Kings, subdues a Deity.
And he that had the strength to rule those graces,
Might never be caught, yet view the brightest faces:
One kiss, and I will no more importune you.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: On that condition, I will grant you one.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: But you must give it me.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: Dian forbid, that were immodesty.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: It must be so.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p:
Upon your Kingly Oath,
Never hereafter to renew your suit.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Now by my crown I swear.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: Take it.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
It is done:
And with this kiss, a second Fire begun,
More ardent are my thoughts now than before:
I loved thee well, but now I love thee more.
Thou shalt not leave me, but for ever dwell,
Where I abide, thy absence is my hell.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: Think on your Oath.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: At Lovers' perjury, the Gods themselves do wink.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
A King say so, pardon me sir, your will I will not obey.
But your oath broken, mainly run away.

body.stage: Enter the Queene, hauing heard their conference.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
So, so, so: This is the affection that you bear to me?
Thinks the French King I will not revenge this wrong?
As I am Queen of France, I will make her know,
What it is to be corival in my Love:
She dies by Heaven.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
If thou but spoil a hair,
Or shed one drop of her celestial blood
For any courtesy I have offered her,
My wrath shall: as a fury haunt the deed.
And I will torment thee for such cruelty,
Worse than the damned in the world below.
I seldom threaten, but I do it straight,
Her death thy Hell, look to it, it is a shrewd fate.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
He ever yet was sovereign of his word,
What shall I do, brooke this corivalship?
No, since I cannot in the Realm of France,
Have the revenge my longing heart desires,
Elsewhere I will seek it, I of late beheld
An English Lord in favour at the Court,
His Name Fitzwaters, and I love him well:
By his procurement I will lay a plot,
To yield King Iohn unto his enemies,
So to obtain my purpose, if it take
However Fools may think to project ill,
It likes me well, because I have my will.

body.stage: Enter a Frenchman and an Englishman.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: An Englishman and a traveller; what are you?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: A Frenchman, and no traveller.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Then give way; For I am the better man.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: The better man?

sp.speaker: Englishm:
sp.p:
Aye, the better man, by the perambulation
of two or three thousand miles, I have seen the great Turk
borrow Money, and never mind the repayment of it.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p:
Peuh, is that all? we have a number of great
Christians that will do so, and when a man comes to
demand his own somewhat boldly, he shall be committed
to prison, or made a Fool, to stand waiting at
the foredore where the Coach stands, whiles the Lord
steals out at the back door by water.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p:
That our Tradesmen can tell, to their great
hindrance, and I myself know this, that being in poverty,
a Lord called me by my name thrice, but he would
not remember it once, when he came to his Lands.

sp.speaker: Englishman.
sp.p:
The reason is, lest thou shouldst beg
some of his New-living.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: Nay rather for fear of paying the old score.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p:
Sure thou art some Nobleman's bastard, thou
canst tell their tricks so right.

sp.speaker: French.
sp.p:
And by some great woman: For I can tell
you their tricks too.

sp.speaker: English.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: French.
sp.p:
Your only fine Lady is wantonness, and new
Fashions, your Citizens wife gallops after.
But she is not so well horsed to overtake her.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p:
Now we are in the discourse of women,
What Countrywomen dost thou love best?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: I love none.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p:
I love all, and to kiss them after the fashion
of all Nations.

sp.speaker: Frenchm.
sp.p:
Why I pray sir, do not all Nations kiss
alike?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p:
You are no Traveller, and therefore I will bear
with your ignorance: but know this, your Spaniard, as
he is proud, he kisses proudly, as if he scorned the
touch of a Ladies lip; marry you Frenchmen draw it
in, as if he would swallow her alive: Now the Italian
has soon done with the upper parts, to be tickling
of the lower: and we Englishmen can never take enough
at both ends.

sp.speaker: Frenchm:
sp.p: Is not your name Master do much?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p:
It is, and yours (I think should be Monsieur
do little.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p:
We are somewhat a kin in the first
part of our names, and I pray heartily let us be better
acquainted together.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p:
You must do as I do then, and since we
were both appointed, to wait here for the French
Queen's coming, let us take her gold, and forswear
ourselves.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: Here comes her Majesty.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
Are you resolved to undergo this charge?
It is but an Oath, which I will guild with Crowns,
And bear you out against the Law.

sp.speaker: Frenchm:
sp.p:
I can do little being so animated, if
I should not forswear myself, for so fair a
Queen.

sp.speaker: Englishm:
sp.p:
And I will do as much as your Majesty
will have me do.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
Take this in earnest, and when it is done, you
shall have more.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: We will.

sp.speaker: Englishman.
sp.p:
And from this time forwards, let us be
forsworn brothers.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: I will instruct you: Here comes Fitzwaters.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
According to your Majesty's command,
I come to know your pleasure for the Letter
I should deliver to the English King,
With that base strumpet that has Injured you.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
There is the Letter, which I charge you
bear unto King Edward, and assure his Grace
I will perform what I have promised in it,
I will send the strumpet to you instantly.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.p:
I know not by what influence I am fallen
Into the affection of this potent Queen:
But she has sworn she loves me as her soul:
And to enjoy me in her amorous Bed,
Would spend the revenues of the Crown of France
Were it her own: I will temporise with her,
To effect some plot upon my Sovereign's foes,
But she shall know, Although she love me well,
My hearts desires were drowned with Floramell.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p:
By all descriptions this should be the man,
To whom I am directed by the Queen:
But whom do I behold the young Fytzwaters?

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.p:
It is she, O no, she is in the Ocean drowned,
No; She escaped it seems as well as I.
But I will take no acquaintance of my Love,
Till she has cleared her from the Queen's suspect.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p:
It is not meet I take acquaintance first,
Nor will I till I know a just cause why,
Of his Familiar dealings with the Queen,
Here is the key her Highness promised you.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
And you the prisoner to be safe locked up,
For your incontinence and wanton life.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p:
You do me wrong, I hate incontinence,
Nor did I ever love a wanton life:
I am a desolate Lady, shipwrecked here,
And had a Husband once, too like thy looks,
But not of such a rude condition.
O were he present, and should hear thee speak
Such boisterous terms against his honoured wife,
He would out of the virtue of his mind
Knowing my conversation to be good,
Write this base slander in thy villain's blood.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
So confident, her innocence is great,
That can do this sincerely without tricks:
But if you be the same that you would seem,
How comes that your reputations grown,
Into such scandal, and your name the theme,
Of every idle fellow in the Court?
That Grooms report, fair Infortunate is
The French Kings love: Nay worse his concubine.
The voice of men is held the voice of God:
And where an evil is so far proclaimed,
The generality approves the guilt,
And she is unworthy to survive a minute,
To be the separation of two hearts,
Made one by Marriage.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p:
Kill me, kill me then.
Having my sentence, wherefore am I spared?
Or do you take delight to torture me?
Before you serve the Execution?
The Law requires no more but death for Lust.
The lingering is a note of Tyranny.
It is sufficient that the wretch must die,
The sooner done, the lesser cruelty.
But if your conscience urge you to forbeare,
I shall confute your worthless Arguments,
And tell you in the pureness of my soul,
Report is a liar, common talk a Fool.
Waiters and Grooms, light-headed like their plumes,
And those that do attend in Princes' Courts,
Too active and quick-witted to deprave
A Courting they proclaim for a consent,
A favour for the deed, believe them not:
It is too common, this they hourly do,
And think none chaste, but her whom none did woo,

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p: But you did kiss the King.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p:
The Queen did see it,
Urged by constraint, and Kingly violence.
Upon condition he should woo no more:
And for that kiss I am esteemed a whore:
If you believe I am, I pray proceed,
I kissed the King, do you a murderous deed.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
Rise, rise, hereafter, the discourse I will tell,
Mean time Fytzwaters welcomes Floramell.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p:
So then I am honest by your own confession,
But ere I entertain you as a Husband,
I will be resolved what Love has past between
The Queen and you, that you her Agent are,
In such a weighty cause as is my life.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p: Runs the stream this way, is the wind turned thus?

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p: I must know all.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
In sight of Heaven I vow
She is as chaste for any lust from me,
As unborn Infants, and I use her love,
But to advance my sovereign and his Realm.
No other case by honour I protest,
In sign whereof I oppose an innocent breast
Against the sword: if you believe not, kill,
But never man died for a lesser ill.

sp.speaker: Floramel.
sp.p:
I am satisfied, rise love, and let us go,
There is no true joy without some taste of woe.

body.stage: Enter French King, Bastard, Saxon, Trier, and Mentz, Queene.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
Prosperity I think was born in France,
It is so obsequious unto all our acts;
And like a subject waits upon our will:
Tomorrow is this happy interview,
In which Fitz-waters and the Earl of Artoise,
Have promised to surprise the English King,
And the ambitious Palsgraue.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
If it take,
We shall have cause to praise our happiness.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
Take, out of all surmise: and in my thoughts
It is as good already as performed.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: I think no less.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: It is most probable.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Where is the Queen she promised us a mask?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: The Mask is ready.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
Be Jovial Cæsar: mirth began the night:
And we will end it with the like delight.

body.stage: Enter King Edward, the Palsgraue, and Y. Fitz, Floramel, Cullen, & diuers Lords in the Maske, they daunce there.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
We are beholding to you Gentlemen,
For this your Court-ship, pray discover now.

sp.speaker: E. King.
sp.p: We will, and make you all die prisoners.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: King Edward here?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: The Palsgraue.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: All our foes.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: Whose plot was this?

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p: Or is it not a Dream?

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
It is such a Dream you will never wake from:
To talk of this strange admiration,
Which like the night hovers on every eye:
Know that I have deluded you with hopes
Vain, like those villains, which my sword did kill,
And by a Letter to the King delivered,
Sent by your Queen, to be revenged for lust,
I caused his Majesty to enter thus.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: I received them in at the back Gate.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Where is the Lady that has wronged the Queen?

sp.speaker: Y. Fytzw:
sp.p:
Here is is my troth-plight wife,
Freer from that foul imputation,
Than is her Majesty from jealousy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Is she then chaste?

sp.speaker: French King:
sp.p:
I will answer for the Virgin,
By my good Fortunes once, now by my beard,
She is as nobly virtuous of a stranger,
As ever I knew, and though I sought her love,
I never obtained it.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: No, where is my witness?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Son, call them in.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p: What can you swear?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: What must we swear?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p:
I will swear that the Lady is a good Lady,
The Queen a good Queen, and there is an end of swearing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Is this all?

sp.speaker: English.
sp.p:
And more than you should get of me, but
that the Queen gave us gold to say something: but
who have we here sirrah?

sp.speaker: Frenchm.
sp.p:
Players, by this light players: O I love a
play with all my heart.

sp.speaker: English.
sp.p: Begin, begin, we are set.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: That is a brave King.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: That is a brave boy that plays the Queen's part.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: He shall be my Juggler.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p:
And when the play is done, I will be at charges
To bid them all to supper.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p: Away with them.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: I am very sleepy.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Would I were a bed.

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.p: I will lead you thither.

sp.speaker: English.
sp.p: God a mercy good Chamberlain.

sp.speaker: French.
sp.p:
The play is done, and now we must go home.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
But shall the stream turn, this way is my plot
Become so weak? you will believe a Subject
Before a Queen? I have out-shot myself,
In seeking Justice at an enemies hand:
This is a cross beyond the strength of brain;
Sure I shall end my days in Lunacy,
Like one to whom due vengeance is denied,
Because of weakness, on myself I will turn
The fury that should light upon my foe,
Scatter my hair, like chaff before the wind,
Hell in this world dwells in a jealous mind.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.p:
Our revelling has struck day out of night,
And bright Aurora ushers foorth the Sun
To his diurnal course; yet neither night,
Day, nor the morning, with her flaring beams,
Can stir up valour in this Saxons breast:
What, is thy mind made captive with thy body?
Or thinkst thou that I take advantages
Where honour should be showed, I am still myself
Ready to give an answer to thy challenge
As at the first, and if thou conquerest me,
By my Achievements I will set thee free.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p:
You show yourself in this a Noble foe,
And I receive more honour than I hoped:
I thought, because I was your prisoner,
You had esteemed captivity a conquest.
But since you have awaked sleeping valour,
And given your Captive such a privilege:
I am the same bold combatant to dare,
And do as much as erst I did intend.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
Choose your own Weapons, and I will
meet you straight.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: My Armour there.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p:
Clinton and bold Fytzwaters are arrived,
And bring with them released from servitude
Brandenberg, Sauoy, and Bohemia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Guide them in.

body.stage: Enter Old Fytzwaters, Clinton, Drum, and Collours, with Sauoy, Brandenberg, and Bishops, with Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Old Fytzw:
sp.p:
These with ourselves, we humbly do
present unto your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p:
Such as our Swords by a glorious victory
set free.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
When Heaven is pleased to give prosperity,
How it flowes in: welcome my honoured Friends: I am
glad your thraldoms prove your liberty.

sp.speaker: Sanoy.
sp.p: The King of England has been always kind.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.p: I have ever found it so.

sp.speaker: Brandenb:
sp.p: And so have I.

sp.speaker: Old Fytzw:
sp.p:
Whom do I see? my Son that stole
my Bride? As you respect my service (gracious King)
Let me have Justice.

sp.speaker: Clint:
sp.p: Clinton kneels with him.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p:
To their great service, greater I oppose,
And do beseech your Highness wrong me not.

sp.speaker: Old Fyztw:
sp.p: Wrong thee?

sp.speaker: Y. Fytzw:
sp.p:
Aye wrong me, may not Kings do wrong?
Or dare you think because you are my Father, I will
lose my wife.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: Daughter come from him, lest I force you hither.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p: Father I may not.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p: Fathers both she shall not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
We will hear no more of these bold menaces
On pain of death I charge you both forbeare:
And let my censure sway this difference.
In England at your house the Bishop told me
That Clintons Daughter by a precontract,
Was young Fytzwaters wife; and that some trick
Betwixt the Fathers to preserve their wealth,
Broke off the match, to have him wed the old.
This being true; I charge you on your lives
Urge him no further in his lawful choice,
But as it was wrong enough to hinder it,
Make him amends, by being reconciled.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p: Which I entreat upon a duteous knee.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.p: And so do I.

sp.speaker: Old Fytzw.
sp.p:
Rise, rise, I am friends with you both, and
When my Angers over you shall find me a kind Father.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: So shall you.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.p: All lets are now removed, I am truly happy.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.p: The Combatants are ready.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Guide them in.

body.stage: Enter seuerally Saxon and the Palsgraue Armd, and in theyr shyrts, Drum & Cullors

sp.speaker: Palsgr.
sp.p:
Idle are words where we must use our swords,
Yet that it may appear what minds we bear,
Now we are marched into this dreadful Lists,
Know that this day my Honour shall exceed.
Or I lie breathless where I set my foote.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p:
Were thy breast Marble, and thy ribs of brass,
Saxon will have the superiority,
Or in this dreadful place, his life expires.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p: Sound trumpets, and the destinies guide all.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: The Palsgraue is invincible I think.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Not to be overcome.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: Nor to be tamed by any.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p:
Matchless, and far beyond the praise of
words, are all thy actions, let me honour thee.

sp.speaker: Plasgraue.
sp.p: Our Friends returned in safety there is more joy.

sp.speaker: F.King.
sp.p:
Cæsar resign your Title unto Sauoy, and Sauoy,
sit you up, whilst the Electors here join all their
hands to make thee Emperor.

sp.speaker: Palsgr:
sp.p: Mine as the first.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.p:
And to get your love,
We will disgrace ourselves to honour him.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
Receive the Crown, but as he wears
the same may it crush out his brains.

sp.speaker: Palsgr.
sp.p: Long live and happily the German Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Sauoy.
sp.p:
As happily as your kind loves have made me,
And long as please the Heavens.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p:
You farther rights shall be performed with
State in Germany, whither I invite the Majesty of
England, and all our Friends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I will bear you company.

sp.speaker: Palsgr:
sp.p:
Fair winds and prosperous to our several
Realms, we wish and pray for, it is not our least good
To be the Favourites of the waving Flood.
